title: 114_hr2990
content: The Act titled "Accelerating Individuals into the Workforce Act" supports subsidized employment for TANF recipients through demonstration projects. Section 403 of the Social Security Act is amended to include grants for subsidized employment demonstration projects aimed at helping low-income individuals secure and maintain employment through wage subsidies. States applying for grants must outline how subsidies will be provided, their duration, amount, structure, and how employers will be recruited to participate. The subsidized employment program aims to help low-income individuals secure and maintain employment through wage subsidies. States must describe how participants can retain employment after the subsidy ends and coordinate efforts with other programs. Funds can be used to subsidize wages for up to 12 months. The subsidized employment program allows for funds to be used to subsidize wages for eligible recipients, ensuring that the total federal funds used do not exceed 50 percent of the recipient's wages. Eligible recipients include those receiving assistance under State programs or noncustodial parents of minor children receiving assistance. The subsidized job program provides wage subsidies for unemployed individuals with incomes below 200 percent of the poverty line. States receiving grants must ensure that no participant is displaced by the program. The subsidized job program provides wage subsidies for unemployed individuals with incomes below 200 percent of the poverty line. States must establish a grievance procedure for resolving complaints of alleged violations related to job displacement. The subsidized job program provides wage subsidies for unemployed individuals. States must report on the number of individuals employed with these funds, the structure of the employment subsidies, and the percentage of eligible recipients who received a subsidy. The subsidized job program requires states to report on the percentage of eligible recipients who received a subsidy and are in unsubsidized employment during the 2nd and 4th quarters after the subsidy ended. The Secretary will conduct a high-quality evaluation of the demonstration project in consultation with each state. The evaluation of a demonstration project must be conducted by an evaluator with experience in rigorous evaluations, using experimental designs or other reliable methodologies for strong causal inferences. Results of the evaluation will be publicly disclosed on the Secretary's website. The Secretary will publish evaluation results on the Department of Health and Human Services website for public access. Recommendations will be submitted to Congress to enhance employment opportunities for individuals receiving state assistance. $100,000,000 will be reserved for this purpose from the fiscal year 2017 budget. 15% of the reserved funds will be used for career pathways programs. The Secretary will allocate 15 percent of reserved funds to support career pathway programs as defined in the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act. States must spend funds provided in the fiscal year or the following year. The amendment made by this Act will be effective on October 1, 2016.
